title: Why is the universe mostly vacuum? Did the vacuum exist before the Big Bang? What would happen if there is no vacuum? - Quora

response.answer_text: I do not understand. The universe is not mostly vacuum. Or rather, vacuum is relative. Vacuum just means “there is a lot less stuff there than there is here”, really. There are lots of things that seem pretty “non-vacuum” in space that we would consider a vacuum on the surface of the Earth. Here we usually consider anything below about 25 Torr a medium vacuum and anything below about 0.0001 Torr a hard vacuum. The ‘surface’ of the sun has a density of about [math]10^{-4} kg/m^3[/math]. If that were air then this would correspond to about 0.070 Torr (70 mTorr)… a pretty good medium vacuum. Is the sun a vacuum? (Interestingly the sun is a lot less dense than we usually think of… it doesn’t reach the density of water until you are about half way from the ‘surface’ to the centre!)  <source: wikipedia, NASA/SDO (AIA)> So relative to our scale the Sun, or at least a lot of it, is a vacuum. Just a very glowy one! Is the Earth a vacuum? Certainly not by our standards… but compared to, say, degenerate matter in a white dwarf the crust of the Earth is about the same as a hard vacuum has compared to us (about [math]10^9 kg/m^3[/math]). And that white dwarf is basically a vacuum compared to a neutron star (something x [math]10^{17} kg/m^3[/math]). Throw a neutron star at a white dwarf and it will pass through it as if it was just more vacuum. Because relative to that it is — something like the Earth is just a slightly lower grade vacuum to a neutron star! Similarly most objects such as dust clouds and nebulae are hard vacuums by our standards… but they collide and interact and on their scale might as well be considered objects with real substance!  <Veil Nebula: source Hubble Space Telescope. Credit: NASA, ESA, and the Hubble Heritage Team (STScI/AURA)> The structures in this image are caused by collisions of high energy gas. We would call them hard vacuum. The “empty” space around this is also full of material, just at a lower density. And so on. There are very few parts of space that are “empty” (if any), though again it is all relative to the scale.  <large scale structure of the universe: Volker Springel - Max Planck Institute For Astrophysics> So… vacuum is not a simple concept. There is something in most places, more in some places than others. But almost wherever you fix your attention there are things that make that look “full” and things that make that look like a “vacuum”. The reason that you see most of the universe as vacuum is that you happen to live on an above average density bit of that universe, so your scale is set pretty far over to one end. But rest assured, there are plenty of scales (and, who knows, maybe life-forms too) relative to which you are vacuum yourself.

Forget about time, it doesn’t exist unless it is measured by an observer but I will agree that intervals are longer within a more compressed space because many more positions have to be traversed to complete a movement. If you had no vacuum or space then the universe would be static and non moving instead of all things being in constant motion through the existing space of our universe.
